text:
*Are voice and tone _real?_*

Curious to get your thoughts here. I find that execs in particular talk about voice and tone a lot – but aren't always able to articulate what that means to them.

I tend to think that nailing good writing that hits real pain points is most of the work – and that voice/tone exists but ultimately isn't *that* important (relative to how often it gets talked about).

What do you think?

oh my, fun question :slightly_smiling_face:  As you said, voice and tone tends to lack rigor, it's kind of like "brand" and is often too fuzzy to be all that meaningful. But when you HAVE it, it's that something extra that makes your content memorable.

Like a person with truly great style. You remember them because they stand out, they have that something extra. They capture and hold your attention.

It's probably fair to say voice and tone get talked about more than they matter because it's  hard to create a strong voice and tone if you don't naturally have one, but having a unique voice is part of a strong brand, when you have it, it kind of just makes everything easier, better, more memorable.

text: So if we continue with the clothing analogy -- first you have to learn the rules of dressing yourself -- fit, proportion, what colors look good on you, etc. And you can learn that stuff from a book. But style is only developed over years. There's not a shortcut.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text: If you get obsessed with personal style before you know the rules, you end up being that guy wearing a funny hat and colorful suspenders, but whose pants never quite fit right :slightly_smiling_face: So there's an order of operations. A memorable voice and tone can seriously level up strong writing, but a memorable voice and tone over bad writing will never fix bad writing.

text: I really love everything <@UJG12DM1V> said :point_up:Tone conversations are some of the hardest ones I  have with clients. My biggest frustration is with clients B2B SaaS-type folks (execs, a lot of the time) who think that being “professional” has to mean being super buttoned-up to the point of being totally boilerplate and forgettable. Like, they want every post to read like a legal filing.

One of my biggest professional missions in life is to convince folks like that it’s okay - nay, NECESSARY -  to loosen up a bit. It helps you stand out and may even make your customers trust you MORE.

<@UJ48Q1HAP> That last point is interesting. I usually think about the loosening up as a part of good writing, rather than an element of tone.

(Warning: I am not going to be able to articulate this all that well)

If you're writing a legal brief or academic paper, I think yeah it will be more formal. And a personal blog can be flippant.

I agree that B2B SaaS should loosen up, I just tend to think that loosening up is not – in and of itself – a distinctive tone.

Thoughts?
That’s definitely true - but you have to break down resistance to the idea of _having_ a distinctive voice in order to advance to talking about what that voice should be.
I think the Mailchimp Style Guide does a great job of defining “voice” and “tone” and explaining how to operationalize each in content: <https://styleguide.mailchimp.com/voice-and-tone/>

text: Another thing I’ve seen with clients is negative reactions to the “tone” of the piece actually being a trojan horse for concerns about the _content_ of the piece - i.e. that there’s not enough “there” there. If a piece doesn’t feel meaty enough, so to speak, I find clients have a tendency to read it as a tone problem when it’s actually not

I wish a language existed for talking about writing like exists for say, describing the different elements of software engineering. Engineers name EVERYTHING and sometimes it's irritating, but then when you need to have a really nuanced conversation, you have the words :slightly_smiling_face:

So I think "Good writing" absolutely encompasses voice & tone. But if we try to dissect that we end up with all these elements of good writing:
-- Strong title
-- Clear information architecture
-- Good spelling & grammar
-- Accuracy
-- Something to say (the "meatiness" that <@UJ48Q1HAP> is describing)
-- A voice that is unique to your person or company
-- A tone that is appropriate to the channel you're writing for and the subject you're writing about

text: Here is a the v1 guidelines we drafted to help us. When I talk about "voice" I'm talking about how the brand manifests in writing, and tone is the adjustments we make based on the channel or topic.

The distinction between "voice" and "tone" is helpful. "tone" == channel/level of formality, I dig it.

In your example, "opinionated while being open" is a good example of the thing I struggle with. Isn't _all_ good writing opinionated? And when you put forward a perspective, isn't it better writing to acknowledge it as a perspective (based on XYZ evidence) than absolute truth?

Not necessarily calling that one out specifically, just trying to parse how much of the voice/tone conversation is "good writing for all" vs "distinct to the writer/brand"

Yep, I see what you mean. I would agree that good writing is always opinionated. For us, being opinionated is a very core part of our brand -- we distinguish when something is our opinion vs. generally accepted best practice. Employees are encouraged to form and state opinions. It's funny to see people in our Slack community pick this up as well, people frequently say "This is my opinion" before stating their position or even using that to frame the advice they are about to give.

So if you compare our brand to let's say HubSpot, I would say that for HubSpot it's more important that their voice be friendly than opinionated. Sure, they publish a lot of opinionated content, but it's not what makes their content memorable -- what makes it memorable is that it has this casual friendliness to it that works very well for their audience. And that friendliness is reflected in so many aspects of their brand, from calling their meetups "HUGS" to using bright friendly colors.

If the only place our company talked about being opinionated was in this little chart it would be 100% pointless. But  it appears in onboarding docs, we talk about opinions at all-hands meetings, we ask each other to clarify current opinions so in this context we're just saying "here is how to express this aspect of our brand in writing"

user_profile.name: janessalantz

text: And to your point about calling out opinions -- I think that's one way our brand is very different from say, a Gary V. He's suuuuuper opinionated but rarely clarifies that his guidance is just an opinion or pauses to give evidence for what informed his opinion. That's OK, it's on-brand for him, but that would be really off-brand for us. Both opinionated, but two very different ways of expressing it, and that's what I was trying to capture in the example here -- we make a point to clarify what is opinion vs. established best practice or evidence-backed and I think that's how we start to express the "openness". Strong opinions can shut down conversations, we want to express opinions in a way that makes it clear what we believe about the world, but keeps the dialogue open because we're open to change.

And the key point is that your stance needs to be articulated throughout all your work?

text:
Yeah, I think that's about right. Our product introduces a very different way of doing an old thing. So while we've convinced a core group of early users that it's the right way (and they LOVE it), we have a long road ahead of us to change an industry. We're often asking people to do things in a way that feels a little odd to them at first. So for us, it's important that every thing we put out there is opinionated and shows an awareness of that opinion. We can't afford to be sloppy or unconsidered in our thinking.

We talk about our product as being a highly opinionated product, one of our users calls it "a state of mind" :joy:

So again, it's not just random "writing guidelines" or an attempt to make our brand memorable for the sake of being memorable -- it's how we express our brand in writing.

I've been a part of voice & tone exercises before that were much more like "How would we like to sound?" and people are like "we should use memes!" and that's when it felt very pointless, it has to come from your brand, and your brand comes from your target market, positioning, etc.

So exactly what you said above -- it's how we articulate our stance. That stance is articulated in the product we're building, the way we run client engagements, who we see as our target market, and how we write.

text: Great answer. It totally depends on scale. That said, I've hired people in the past to help with backlinks or request guest posts. But ultimately as a blog editor, I am responsible for getting the ranking.

I'd also throw in checking the difficulty of the keyword you are trying to rank for. You may need more backlinks to rank for a more difficult keyword (though that's not always the case). But keyword difficulty shapes a lot of my strategy for which words I pursue first.
